channel.title: ASF Jira
channel.description: This file is an XML representation of an issue

item.title: [CXF-8698] Content-ID of attachments for outgoing requests are URL-decoded instead of URL-encoded
item.description:
We are using camel CXF and we found that for an outgoing request, the Content-ID header of attachments is URL-decoded. We can also see that the Content-ID of incoming requests is also URL-decoded. I would expect that for outgoing requests, the Content-ID would get URL-encoded.

Code: https://github.com/apache/cxf/blob/master/core/src/main/java/org/apache/cxf/attachment/AttachmentSerializer.java#L218

Stacktrace:

"main@1" prio=5 tid=0x1 nid=NA runnable
  java.lang.Thread.State: RUNNABLE
   at org.apache.cxf.attachment.AttachmentSerializer.writeHeaders(AttachmentSerializer.java:218)
   at org.apache.cxf.attachment.AttachmentSerializer.writeProlog(AttachmentSerializer.java:182)
   at org.apache.cxf.interceptor.AttachmentOutInterceptor.handleMessage(AttachmentOutInterceptor.java:77)
   at org.apache.cxf.phase.PhaseInterceptorChain.doIntercept(PhaseInterceptorChain.java:308)
   - locked <0x1538> (a org.apache.cxf.phase.PhaseInterceptorChain)
   at org.apache.cxf.endpoint.ClientImpl.doInvoke(ClientImpl.java:532)

   at org.apache.camel.processor.SharedCamelInternalProcessor.process(SharedCamelInternalProcessor.java:186)
   at org.apache.camel.processor.SharedCamelInternalProcessor.process(SharedCamelInternalProcessor.java:86)
   at org.apache.camel.impl.ProducerCache$1.doInProducer(ProducerCache.java:541)

   at sun.reflect.DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.invoke(DelegatingMethodAccessorImpl.java:43)

item.summary: Content-ID of attachments for outgoing requests are URL-decoded instead of URL-encoded

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are not closed can be reopened.

comments.comment:
We posted this on the mailinglist where Andriy proposed to create this ticket:
Andriy Redko - Tuesday, May 3, 2022 3:04:58 AM GMT+2
Hi Manuel,

Interesting, looking into RFC-2392, which says:

content-id = url-addr-spec
url-addr-spec = addr-spec ; URL encoding of RFC 822 addr-spec

Which basically confirms your observations, looks like a bug to me. Could you please
open an issue here [2]? Thank you.

[1]
https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2392
[2]
https://issues.apache.org/jira/projects/CXF/issues
/

Best Regards,
Andriy Redko

Can someone confirm that this is considered as a bug and that it will be fixed and what the timeline would be?

Thanks in advance
Manuel
Hey mash-sap , looking into it, the history behind is more complicated than I thought, trying to understand how to support different cases

mash-sap the issue (as per my understanding) attributes to flawed CXF's Content-ID conversion implementation which is not possible to resolve in non-breaking fashion:

 - the AttachmentSerializer uses URLDecoder.decode due to https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CXF-7317 (reverting that would cause regression)

 - the AttachmentDeserializer uses URLDecoder.decode which essentially asks for AttachmentSerializer to use URLEncoder.encode on serialization side (which it does not)

 - however, URLEncoder.encode in AttachmentSerializer  would encode everything, including fe email address(es) in Content-ID which it should not URL because of RFC 822 addr-spec:

 addr-spec = local-part "@" domain ; global address

I have a possible fix in mind but it would be helpful to understand what kind of Content-ID you are getting and what exactly is the problem with double decoding  you run into (I suspect consequent decoding of decoded value should be opaque in most case)?

[1] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc822#section-6.1

reta thanks for looking into it. Our customer has a route through scenario where he is using something like myattachm+ent.xml. The customer expects that the outbound call contains the exact same content ID as the incoming message. But + is replace by whitespace, so the content ID changes to myattachm ent.xml.

Best regards,
Manuel
Hey mash-sap , it seems like I found a possible solution, pull request is out https://github.com/apache/cxf/pull/950/files, waiting for reviews.
Great, thanks for taking care of this Andriy. We are running on a CXF fork. Looking forward to pick this change in our codeline. Thank you!

Hi Andriy,

this change is causing outgoing content-ids to be ENCODED. But unfortunately it also breaks the DECODE of incoming message. Content-ID headers do not contain "cid:-prefix as assumed here:
221456a#diff-e3efb80d0a98bbbd7f6eddd3c021c5fb5ab05ea2ee8d97dc68026f6345e5a509R227

So after picking this change, I can see that outgoing headers are encoded but incoming messages are not decoded anymore. So I think there has to be a different condition to decide between en/decoding than the cid-prefix.

Can you check this again?

Best regards,
Manuel
This change is breaking the decoding of the content-id for incoming messages
Hi, is there any update on this topic, reta ?
Hi mash-sap , please check https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CXF-8733, the fix is drafted but working on tests (we should have caught this regression early on), thanks.
Hey mash-sap , the related fix https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/CXF-8733 has been merged, could you please try latest 3.5.4-SNAPSHOTs? Thank you.

Thanks reta . I will pull the change into our fork and report back with the results soon.

Best regards,
Manuel

Hi reta . I can confirm that the filenames are now properly encoded/decoded. One thing I noticed and I'm not sure about the expected behavior is the following:

  1. Filename in camel is Nice+FileName.txt, content-id header will be: Content-ID: <Nice%2BFileName.txt>  --> OK
  2. Filename in camel is cid:Nice+Filename,txt, content-id header will be: <Nice FileName.txt>  --> The filename was decoded instead of encoded. Is this the expected behavior?

Hey mash-sap , thanks a lot for checking and confirming, regarding "cid:", we were trying to follow the RFC-2392 [1]:

            // A "cid" URL is converted to the corresponding Content-ID message
            // header [MIME] by removing the "cid:" prefix, converting the % encoded
            // character to their equivalent US-ASCII characters, and enclosing the
            // remaining parts with an angle bracket pair, "<" and ">".  

[1] https://datatracker.ietf.org/doc/html/rfc2392
